title: Gendered pathways to educational aspirations: The role of academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading
abstract: The aim of this study was to examine lower secondary school students' (N ¼ 1152) pathways to educational aspirations. The study used multi-group structural equation modelling to investigate the predictions of academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement, and interest in mathematics and reading, in relation to educational aspirations for boys and girls. While certain factors were influential for students' academic aspirations irrespective of gender, some interesting differences also emerged. Academic self-concept and interest in reading predicted educational aspirations for both groups. However, gendered pathways emerged in how achievement and interest in mathematics predicted educational aspirations. Interest in mathematics predicted girls' educational aspirations, whereas mathematics achievement was a significant predictor for boys. School burnout had negative indirect effects through interest in reading and mathematics in both groups, but for girls, there was also a direct positive effect on educational aspirations.

abstract.text: The aim of this study was to examine lower secondary school students' (N ¼ 1152) pathways to educational aspirations. The study used multi-group structural equation modelling to investigate the predictions of academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement, and interest in mathematics and reading, in relation to educational aspirations for boys and girls. While certain factors were influential for students' academic aspirations irrespective of gender, some interesting differences also emerged. Academic self-concept and interest in reading predicted educational aspirations for both groups. However, gendered pathways emerged in how achievement and interest in mathematics predicted educational aspirations. Interest in mathematics predicted girls' educational aspirations, whereas mathematics achievement was a significant predictor for boys. School burnout had negative indirect effects through interest in reading and mathematics in both groups, but for girls, there was also a direct positive effect on educational aspirations.

body_text.text: According to previous research, educational aspirationsdthe nature and level of students' academic goalsdare influential not only regarding adolescents' career and occupational decisions and outcomes (Eccles, 2009; Schoon & Parsons, 2002) , but also their overall well-being later in life (Ashby & Schoon, 2012) . The research has also identified several academic and motivational individual difference factors that play a role in the process by which educational aspirations are formed (Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) . Moreover, recent studies have suggested that the pathways to aspirations may, at least in some respect, be different for boys and girls (Watt et al., 2012) . Uncovering the mechanism underlying the 'gendered pathways' to educational aspirations might offer a means of better understanding and intervening in adolescents stereotyped belief-systems. As such beliefsystems may unnecessarily limit future educational choices and occupational possibilities, examining their role in adolescents' goals and plans is important.

Previous research has mainly focused on identifying the predictors of adolescents' educational aspirations in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields (Guo, Marsh, Parker, Morin, & Yeung, 2015; Watt et al., 2012) and, to a lesser degree, within the domain of reading (Durik, Vida, & Eccles, 2006) . Only a few studies have combined the indicators relating to these two academic domains (Nagy, Trautwein, Baumert, K€ oller, & Garrett, 2006; Viljaranta, Nurmi, Aunola, & Salmela-Aro, 2009) . As the effects of performance and motivational beliefs on educational aspirations seem to differ both by gender and academic domain, the importance of examining multiple domains simultaneously to be able to control for the effects of the other domains on educational aspirations, is highlighted.

Furthermore, the factors that researchers have used to predict educational aspirations have mainly included indicators of the students' performance-related outcomes (e.g., grades; Durik et al., 2006) and different sets of motivational beliefs (e.g., self-concept and interest; Nagy et al., 2006) , and largely ignored the factors reflecting the students' psychological well-being. As researchers have found that problems in students' socio-emotional functioning (e.g., school burnout) relate to low academic achievement (Kiuru, Aunola, Nurmi, Leskinen, & Salmela-Aro, 2008) , depression (Bakker et al., 2000; Salmela-Aro, Savolainen, & Holopainen, 2009) , unfavourable motivational tendencies (Tuominen-Soini, Salmela-Aro, & Niemivirta, 2008 , 2012 and educational dropout (Korhonen, Linnanm€ aki, & Aunio, 2014) , we can expect them to play a role also in adolescents' educational aspirations. Consequently, our study aimed to contribute to previous research by (a) examining adolescent students' gendered educational aspirations at the end of compulsory education, using indicators relating to both mathematics and reading, and (b) including an indicator of students' socio-emotional functioning among the predictive variables.

In the following sections we will review the literature in the field. First, educational aspirations are discussed in the light of different operationalisations and gender differences. Second, the most influential predictors of educational aspirations are presented and finally, gendered pathways emerging from these predictors to educational aspirations are acknowledged.

Educational aspirations during adolescence have been studied to explain educational disparities in general, and individuals' occupational choices and attainment later in life, in particular (Domina, Conley, & Farkas, 2011; Rojewski, 2005) . There is no universally accepted definition for the term educational aspirations, but it is generally used as referring to a person's goals and plans within an academic setting (Trebbels, 2015) . Researchers have defined and measured educational aspirations via the number of career plans per adolescents (Mendez & Crawford, 2002) , the prestige of their educational aspirations (Leung, Conoley, & Scheel, 1994; Viljaranta et al., 2009) , and the level of self-set educational goals (Vasalampi, Salmela-Aro, & Nurmi, 2009; Watt et al., 2012) . Educational aspirations have also been theorized as being either idealistic or realistic. While idealistic aspirations refer to the attainment level that the student desires, realistic aspirations reflect the actual perceived likelihood of success and more pragmatic expectations of completing a certain level of education (Rojewski, 2005) . However, in several studies focusing on educational choices, the operationalisations of educational aspirations have covered both idealistic and realistic alternatives, while no clear distinction has been made between the two terms (Chow, Eccles, & Salmela-Aro, 2012; Durik et al., 2006; . There has also been a tendency to examine educational aspirations within a specific academic domain, and the most common domain of interest has been mathematics (Chow et al., 2012; Watt, Eccles, & Durik, 2006) . In some studies, girls have reported higher educational aspirations (Mahaffy & Ward, 2002; Mau & Bikos, 2000) , whereas in other studies, boys' aspirations have been higher (Inoue, 1999; Mendez & Crawford, 2002) . There have also been studies that found no gender differences in educational aspirations (e.g. Ireson & Hallam, 2009; Watt et al., 2012) . Besides the possible gender differences in the level of educational aspirations, it also seems that the processes or paths that lead to these aspirations may differ as a function of gender (Domene et al., 2006; Watt et al., 2012) .

Students' abilities and academic success shape their educational and occupational aspirations. Adolescents' aptitudes (e.g., IQ) and achievement (e.g., grades or grade point average) have been shown to display from moderate to strong effects on the level of educational aspirations (Guo, Marsh, Morin, Parker, & Kaur, 2015; Liu, Cheng, Chen, & Wu, 2009; Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) and later achievement-related choices (e.g., university entry, Schoon, 2008) . In adolescent samples, mathematics (Ozturk, 2006; and reading achievement (Savolainen, Ahonen, Aro, Tolvanen, & Holopainen, 2008) have both been found to influence educational aspirations, and it also seems that the effects within these domains are similar for both genders (Durik et al., 2006; Shapka et al., 2006; Simpkins, Davis-Kean, & Eccles, 2006) . However, there is a lack of studies addressing the effects of both achievement in more than one school domain and gender, at the same time. As an exception, Mau (1995) included mathematics, reading, and science achievement in the prediction of educational aspirations. While achievement in all three domains predicted students' educational aspirations, the role of gender was not addressed. In other words, for now it is not well known whether the effects of mathematics and reading achievement on educational aspirations would differ when considered simultaneously, and as a function of gender.

Moreover, academic abilities and achievement are not, by themselves, sufficient factors to explain students' educational aspirations and choices. For example, it is a familiar phenomenon identified in several countries that irrespective of adolescent girls' high mathematics and science grades, they are underrepresented in advanced STEM courses and occupational fields (Ceci & Williams, 2010; Else-Quest, Hyde, & Linn, 2010) . Further, it has been documented that along with the possible direct effects, the influence of academic achievement may be indirect, mediated by different motivational constructs (Parker, Nagy, Trautwein, & Lüdtke, 2014) . Besides cognitive abilities, students' motivational beliefs play a crucial role in educational goal-setting and decision-making processes (Eccles, 2009) .

According to prominent theories of motivation (e.g., the expectancy-value model, self-concept and interest theories), both students' competence-related perceptions (e.g., self-concept) and value-laden motivational beliefs (e.g., utility and interest perceptions) are influential in terms of the nature and level of academic goals (Eccles, 2009; Wigfield & Cambria, 2010) . While competence perceptions seem to ensure that the goal is experienced as attainable (i.e., one has sufficient ability and skills to reach it), the perceived value of the engagement itselfdintrinsic interest in learning or in specific academic domain, for exampledsupports persistence and commitment to the goal (Hofer, 2010; Schunk & Pajares, 2005) .

Several studies have investigated the relationship between motivational beliefs and educational aspirations. In general, individual differences in competence perceptions (Ireson & Hallam, 2009) and interest (Nagy et al., 2006) have been the most powerful predictors Wigfield & Eccles, 1992) . In many of the studies, students' competence perceptions have been conceptualized through self-concept da mental representation of one's personal competencies in academic domains in general, or in relation to a specific school-subject (Marsh & Craven, 1997; Marsh, Craven, & Debus, 1991) . In addition to educational aspirations , academic or domainspecific self-concept has been shown to be positively associated with students' academic achievement (Marsh, Hau, & Kong, 2002; Valentine, DuBois, & Cooper, 2004) , interest (Viljaranta, Tolvanen, Aunola, & Nurmi, 2014) , and students' overall psychological wellbeing (Chui & Wong, 2016; Marsh, Trautwein, Ludtke, K€ oller, & Baumert, 2006) . In fact, current research suggests a reciprocal developmental relationship between achievement, self-concept, and interest, with a strengthening tendency during the school years (Denissen, Zarrett, & Eccles, 2007; M€ oller, Retelsdorf, K€ oller, & Marsh, 2011) .

body_text.text: Educational aspirations have also been positively predicted by intrinsic value and domain-specific interest Watt et al., 2012) , d the latter being close to the concept of individual interest, a tendency to re-engage and enjoy a particular content domain (Frentzel, Goetz, Pekrun, & Watt, 2010; Renninger & Hidi, 2011) . Individual interest towards an academic domain is likely to develop when engagement with it is experienced as inherently rewarding (Renninger & Su, 2012) . Once interest deepens, it becomes intertwined with students' personal values, and may even form a part of one's identity (Renninger, 2009:; Renninger & Hidi, 2011) . Previous studies have shown interest to predict educational choices (Gottfried, Marcoulides, Gottfried, & Oliver, 2013) , whereas academic self-concept is a stronger predictor of achievement (Nagy et al., 2006; Perez, Cromley, & Kaplan, 2014) . However, in their recent cross-cultural study, Watt et al. (2012) found that self-concept and interest predicted educational aspirations differently depending on the culture. The researchers explained their finding by the differing educational contexts that emphasized and valued individual choice and achievement-related outcomes differently.

These results may be taken to illustrate the notion that both selfconcept and interest represent personal belief-and value-systems that are prone to stereotypical identifications and biases (Eccles, 2009) . Culture, education, family, and peer-groups convey stereotypical expectations and values that shape students' beliefs about what they are expected to be good at and which academic domains are typically valued within their reference-group (Cvencek, Meltzoff, & Greenwald, 2011; Tomasetto, Mirisola, Galdi, & Cadinu, 2015) . One of the most salient reference-groups that children and adolescents become identified with, and which also has been shown to play a role in the formation of students' motivational beliefs, is gender (Cvencek, Kapur, & Meltzoff, 2015) . In a number of studies it has been shown that from early school years onwards, girls' and boys' self-concepts differ depending on the academic domain (Herbert & Stipek, 2005 ; see Spinath, Eckert, & Steinmayr, 2014 ; for a review), and that they are more likely to show interest in gender-typical academic contents (Fredricks & Eccles, 2002) . These kinds of stereotypical self-evaluations (e.g., domain-specific selfconcept and interest) have been suggested to work as mediators between academic achievement and students' educational aspirations and choices (Eccles & Wang, 2016) .

Besides mediation effects, it has been suggested that gendered motivational beliefs might also exert moderation effects, thus influencing the relational patterns between motivational beliefs and educational outcomes (Eccles, 2009) . However, the results of testing such a hypothesis have been not only scarce but also mixed. In some studies, no relational differences have been observed (Simpkins et al., 2006) , while a few have identified certain differences as a function of gender (Watt et al., 2012) . For example, Watt et al. (2012) found that among Australian high-schoolers, mathematics intrinsic value predicted the level of students' general educational aspirations for girls but not for boys. Most notably, the observed effect was negative, showing that female adolescents with higher intrinsic value for mathematics held lower educational aspirations.

As summarized above, the level of students' educational aspirations is supported by different motivational and cognitive factors that can also be considered as individuals' psychological resources that facilitate their goal commitment. One of the less studied, but highly relevant resources is students' socio-emotional well-being that has been found to be related to students' motivational tendencies during adolescence, and to bear consequences for later educational and occupational trajectories (Samuel, Bergman, & Hupka-Brunner, 2013; Tuominen-Soini et al., 2008 , 2012 .

While there is no general consensus on the definition of students' well-being, it is most often considered to comprise several sub-dimensions, covering both positive (e.g., self-esteem) and negative (e.g., stress) indicators (Pollard & Lee, 2003) . In this study, well-being is examined in relation to educational context (i.e., academic well-being), and restricted to the examination of burnout, which may develop as a result of high imbalance between perceived demands and personal resources (Salmela-Aro & Upadyaya, 2014a). School burnout has been defined through dimensions that describe students' exhaustion due to school-related demands, cynicism and detached attitude towards schooling, and feelings of inadequacy as a student (Salmela-Aro, Kiuru, Leskinen, & Nurmi, 2009) . These dimensions have been shown to be associated with adolescent students' motivational strivings, whereby a tendency to minimize schoolwork and effort (i.e., work avoidance orientation) increases the likelihood of cynicism and sense of inadequacy. It is also noteworthy that even high-achieving and motivated students, and especially girls, have been found to be vulnerable to exhaustion (Tuominen-Soini & Salmela-Aro, 2014; Tuominen-Soini et al., 2012) . In general, the overall mean-level trend seems to be that girls are more likely to report higher levels of school burnout than boys (Salmela-Aro & Tynkkynen, 2012; Salmela-Aro, .

Studies on the relationship between school burnout and educational aspirations are still scarce. Vasalampi et al. (2009) found that school burnout negatively predicted educational aspirations for girls, but not for boys during the upper secondary school years. However, they did not control for other possibly relevant predictors, such as academic self-concept or interest. In another study examining trajectories of school burnout among Finnish adolescents across their transition to post-comprehensive education, it was found that adolescents with lower level of educational aspirations were more likely to belong to the high-decreasing school burnout group, than to groups with either low-increasing or lowstable school burnout profiles (Salmela-Aro & Upadyaya, 2014b). Moreover, comparisons between genders revealed that girls were over represented in the high-decreasing burnout group.

In the expectancy-value framework, some studies have also examined how self-perceived drawbacks predict educational choices (Perez et al., 2014) . The concept of cost has been utilized to describe the perceived negative consequences of engaging in learning, such as required effort, or psychological well-being (see Eccles et al., 1983 ; for a detailed discussion). In addition, these studies have identified that cost measures predict and correlate negatively with students' interest (Flake, Barron, Hulleman, McCoach, & Welsh, 2015; Gaspard et al., 2015) and educational aspirations (Battle & Wigfield, 2003; Luttrell et al., 2010; Perez et al., 2014) . In fact, the conceptualisations (and operationalizations) of cost and school burnout seem to share some common features. The exhaustion component of school burnout is related to both dimensions of cost, namely, the amount of effort and emotional and psychological demands, whereas inadequacy and cynicism are more similar to the latter (Flake et al., 2015; Gaspard et al., 2015; Salmela-Aro, Kiuru et al., 2009) . However, there are also some important differences between school burnout and cost. First, school burnout is a more general negative emotion toward school (Salmela-Aro, Savolainen et al., 2009) , whereas cost is more domain-or situation-specific (Wigfield & Eccles, 2000) . Second, school burnout develops over a longer period of time, whereas cost is more situational and anticipatory. In fact, arguably, school burnout could be regarded as a consequence of experiencing prolonged cost (Schaufeli & Bakker, 2004; Tuominen-Soini et al., 2008) . To summarize, despite the differences, both phenomena have been theorized and shown to hinder student motivation and engagement by tying up and burdening their psychological resources and decreasing positive affect ; Salmela-Aro & Upadyaya, 2014a; Tuominen-Soini & Salmela-Aro, 2014). As a consequence, students' capability and desire to set and achieve ambitious educational goals may also be diminished (Nurmi & Salmela-Aro, 2002 ).

Studies focusing solely on one academic domain have found mixed results concerning the gender differences in the relations (i.e., moderator effects) between motivational beliefs and educational aspirations (e.g., Durik et al., 2006; Watt et al., 2012) . Interestingly, in studies contrasting two or more academic domains, gender has been found to moderate the effects of motivational beliefs on educational aspirations and choices. For example, Nagy et al. (2006) demonstrated that during secondary school, boys' self-concept and interest in mathematics affected their decisionmaking concerning advanced biology course choices, whereas for girls, the choices in mathematics and biology were independent of the contrasted domain's motivational beliefs. In line with this, a few studies utilising a person-centred methodological approach have investigated how an intra-individual hierarchy concerning interest in different domains predicts educational aspirations (Chow & Salmela-Aro, 2011; Chow et al., 2012; Viljaranta et al., 2009; Watt, 2005) . Echoing the gender-typical mean level differences, in these studies, boys were observed to be more likely to have a profile of high interest or task-values in mathematics and science compared to girls, who were more likely to display a profile with high reading interest (Chow et al., 2012; Viljaranta et al., 2009) . While in Chow et al. (2012) , the interest profiles fully mediated the relationship between gender and educational aspirations in physical and IT -related sciences, Viljaranta et al. (2009) found that their task-value profiles predicted educational aspirations for girls but not for boys. They hypothesized that boys' educational aspirations might originate from an objective criterion (e.g., academic achievement), whereas girls seemed to base their expectations on broader considerations, including their values and motivation.

One possible approach for discussing these, and the results of studies incorporating two domains in the prediction of educational aspirations, is the internal/external frame (I/E) of reference model (Marsh, 1986; Marsh et al., 2015) . The model postulates that students' self-perceptions are dependent not only on social (external) comparisons, but also on dimensional (internal) comparisons, in which achievement in one school subject is evaluated in reference to another school subject (M€ oller, Pohlmann, K€ oller, & Marsh, 2009) . Traditionally, this model has been used to explain the relations between mathematics and verbal achievement and selfconcept. In the external comparison process, high mathematics achievement is supposed to lead to higher mathematics selfconcept and high verbal achievement to higher verbal selfconcept. However, according to the internal comparison process, higher mathematics achievement will result in lower verbal selfconcept, after the effect of verbal achievement is taken into account. Consequently, while students achieving well in mathematics also often perform well in reading, they consider themselves "as being good at" mainly one or the other of the domains. There are robust findings across age groups, gender, and countries concerning the presence of this mechanism (M€ oller et al., 2009) .

The I/E model has also been extended to intrinsic motivation (Marsh et al., 2015) , and the expectancy-value model in general (Eccles, 2009) . According to Eccles (2009) , the external and internal comparisons of one's abilities and values are also a natural part of adolescents' identity development process, whereby they start to identify themselves more strongly with some academic domains than with others. This identification process, in turn, is likely to be influenced by gender stereotypes: out of two academic domains that an adolescent achieves well in, he or she will be more prone to emphasize and prefer the one that corresponds to the gendertypical expectations and norms. As a consequence, adolescents' academic choice behaviour and expectations concerning their educational and occupational goals may be influenced as well (e.g., Nagy et al., 2006; Parker et al., 2012) .

At the end of compulsory education in the Finnish school system (grade 9), students choose between upper secondary general education (academic track) and vocational education (vocational track)done of the most important decisions affecting the level of education that they will attain (Nyyss€ ol€ a, 2004). Therefore, understanding which factors influence students' educational aspirations during this critical transition phase is important. This study adds to the existing literature in several ways. First, to our knowledge, no study has combined mathematics achievement and interest and reading achievement and interest to predict educational aspirations. This approach allows us to examine, whether achievement and motivational beliefs related to one or the other of the subjectsd mathematics and readingdare more important for students' educational aspirations, and whether the predictive effects vary as a function of gender. Second, only a few studies have examined the relationship between school burnout and educational aspirations (Salmela-Aro & Upadyaya, 2014b; Vasalampi et al., 2009 ).

Our hypothetical model ( Fig. 1 ) was constructed based on theoretical considerations and previous empirical results. First, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading, academic self-concept, and school burnout were all set to predict educational aspirations directly. Second, given that domain-specific motivational beliefs mediate the effect of achievement on educational aspirations (Eccles, 2009; Parker et al., 2014) , interest in mathematics and reading were examined as mediators between achievement measures and educational aspirations. Third, as the indicators of students' socio-emotional strain have also been shown to influence domain-specific motivational beliefs negatively (Flake et al., 2015; Gaspard et al., 2015) , both direct and indirect effects of school burnout through interests on educational aspirations were tested.
Accordingly, we set the following research questions:

1. How do reading achievement and interest predict girls' and boys' educational aspirations? 2. How do mathematics achievement and interest predict girls' and boys' educational aspirations? 3. How does academic self-concept predict educational aspirations for boys and girls? 4. How does school burnout predict interest in reading and mathematics and educational aspirations for boys and girls?

Given that the empirical evidence on the moderating role of gender with regard to the research questions 1 and 2 is both contradictory and scarce, we did not set any gender-specific hypotheses concerning the effects of achievement and interest in mathematics and reading on educational aspirations. While on the one hand, based on gender-typical internal and external frame of reference ejudgements (Eccles, 2009) , it would be possible that the effects might differ according to gender, on the other hand, support from previous studies is as yet neither sufficient nor consistent. Concerning question 3, we expected academic self-concept to predict educational aspirations positively (e.g., . Finally, we expected school burnout to show negative effects on students' interests and educational aspirations (Flake et al., 2015; Gaspard et al., 2015; Salmela-Aro & Upadyaya, 2014b).

The sample of the present study consisted of 1152 students (576 boys, 576 girls) from 14 comprehensive schools in Swedishspeaking 1 areas of Finland, representing approximately one-third of the Swedish-speaking age group. The students were completing the ninth grade (mean age ¼ 15.8 years, SD ¼ 4.9 months) and were in the process of making their choices for upper secondary education at the time of the data collection. The participating schools were chosen so that the sample would be representative of the Swedish-speaking population.

We employed the standardised KTLT arithmetic skills test to assess the students' mathematical skills (R€ as€ anen & Leino, 2005) . This scale assesses students' performance in basic arithmetic (addition, subtraction, multiplication and division), word problemsolving, algebra, geometry and unit conversion skills. Schools also use it for screening purposes, to identify at-risk students in mathematics learning. The KTLT is a paper-and-pencil test containing 40 items, is intended for Grades 7 through 9 (13e16 years), and consists of 4 parallel versions (A, B, C and D versions). Students have 40 min to complete the test.

Klassdiagnoser i l€ asning och skrivning f€ or h€ ogstadiet och gymnasiet (LS) reading ability test (Johansson, 2005 ) is a standardised test for Grades 7 through 9 (13e16 years) and Grade 1 in upper secondary school (16e17 years). The test identifies students with reading difficulties. The subtests in the present study were word comprehension and reading comprehension tests.

2.2.2.1. Word comprehension. The items measure the students' word comprehension skills in Swedish. There are 40 sentences in which the last word is missing. Five words are listed after the sentence, and the students must choose the most appropriate word to end the sentence.

The items measure students' reading comprehension skills in Swedish. There are five short texts that the students must read. Then they must choose the correct title for each text from four suggestions and subsequently choose the correct statements from six statements about the content of the text.

We measured academic self-concept using eight items from the Perceived Competence Scale for Children (Harter, 1982) . The original scale consists of 28 items, of which 7 items measure academic self-concept. We used a modified version of the academic selfconcept scale that included one additional item (see Korhonen et al., 2014) . For each item in the academic self-concept scale, there were two statements. First, the students had to decide if they were more like the young person described on the left-hand side of the statement or more like the one depicted on the right-hand side. Second, they had to mark whether the statement (e.g. 'Like school, doing well; Understand what I read') was completely true or just partly true for them. We scored the responses on a four-point scale ranging from least competent (1) to most competent (4). The original scale was in English; consequently, we needed to assure the validity of the instrument translation. Since the scale was also available in Finnish and Norwegian, a multi-language team translated the questionnaire from Norwegian to Swedish and from Finnish to Swedish, and compared the two translations to determine their similarity.

To measure students' interest in mathematics and Swedish (i.e., mother tongue), we used teacher ratings due to the fact that students' self-reports with regard to these constructs were not available. Students' mathematics and Swedish teachers were asked to evaluate their students' motivation and activity in class and rate the students' interest in these subjects on a five-point Likert scale. They received a name list of their students by class (e.g., class 9b) and were requested to fill in the ratings for every student. Teacherreports on students' interest and motivation have been used in several studies focusing on younger children (Baroody & Diamond, 2013; Edens & Potter, 2013; Fisher, Dobbs-Oates, Doctoroff, & Arnold, 2012; Pakarinen et al., 2011) , and they have been found to relate to students' self-reports (Guthrie et al., 2004; Wigfield et al., 2008) , to observational data on students' motivational engagement (e.g., enjoyment and participation, Baroody & Diamond, 2013; Fisher et al., 2012) , thus lending support for the validity of the measures. Further, in their study among adolescents, Dicke, Lüdtke, Trautwein, Nagy, and Nagy (2012) reported that teacher ratings of students' mastery motivation statistically significantly predicted corresponding student ratings in five different school subjects. Consequently, while not being extensively studied, there is evidence supporting the use of teacher-ratings as indicators of student motivation and interest (see also, Wigfield & Cambria, 2010) . However, it is important to acknowledge that we do not claim them to be identical with students' self-reports. It is highly likely that the measures by different raters capture different aspects of the phenomenon, teachers focusing more on students' observable behaviour (e.g., attention focusing and participation) in classroom situations (Friedrich, Jonkmann, Nagengast, Schmitz, & Trautwein, 2013; Kaiser, Retelsdorf, Südkamp, & M€ oller, 2013) .

body_text.text: We used the School Burnout Inventory (SBI) to assess school burnout; it is a nine-item scale, which Salmela-Aro and N€ a€ at€ anen (2005) developed. The inventory consists of three subscales: exhaustion at school (EXH) (e.g., 'I feel overwhelmed by my schoolwork'), cynicism toward the meaning of school (CYN) (e.g., 'I feel that I am losing interest in my schoolwork') and sense of inadequacy as a student (INAD) (e.g., 'I often have feelings of inadequacy in my schoolwork'). We assessed the items using a sixpoint Likert scale ranging from one (completely disagree) to six (completely agree). However, we excluded one item measuring exhaustion from the questionnaire due to a mistake in the data planning process (item: 'The pressure of my schoolwork causes me problems in my close relationships with others'). A multi-language team translated the scale from Finnish to Swedish.

We measured students' idealistic and realistic educational aspirations according to two statements on a three-point Likert scale (vocational upper secondary education, polytechnic education, university education): 'Highest academic degree I want to achieve' and 'Highest academic degree I will probably achieve'.
Descriptive statistics, reliability coefficients and correlations between all the variables by gender are presented in Table 1 .

First, we conducted a pilot study with 20 students from the same class to assess the questionnaire. The questionnaire worked well in terms of length and clarity, and we did not need to make changes on the basis of the pilot study. The students completed the LS reading test during OctobereDecember 2007 and the KTLT test and questionnaire between January and April 2008. Along with trained research assistants (5 undergraduate students), we performed (First and third author) the data collection for this study. We took the measurements with the groups of students in their own schools during teacher-selected lessons. It took approximately 2 lessons (45min/lesson) to collect the data for the LS test, 1 lesson for the KTLT test, and 1 lesson for the questionnaire.

We handled missing data by imputing missing values using the expectation-maximisation (EM) algorithm (Dempster, Laird, & Rubin, 1977) . Moreover, we utilized the MPLUS (version 7) program (Muth en & Muth en, 1998e2013) to conduct all of the analyses. Previous research has shown that the items from the mathematics test load on a single mathematics factor, whereas word and reading comprehension items load on a reading factor (Korhonen, Linnanm€ aki, & Aunio, 2012) . In line with this, we randomly parcelled the 40 math items into 4 item parcels. We then used these parcels as factor indicators for the mathematics construct. The benefits of parcelling include decreased error variances, fewer non-normalities, increased common variance, model parsimony and improved model fit (Bandalos, 2002) . We expected that the items measuring academic self-concept from Harter's Perceived Competence Scale for Children (1982) would load on a single academic self-concept factor. On the basis of previous research (Salmela-Aro, Kiuru et al., 2009; Tuominen-Soini et al., 2012) , we expected that items from the SBI would load on three separate factors (EXH, CYN and INAD), and that these would serve as indicators of a higher order overall school burnout factor. We used the two statements concerning educational aspirations as factor indicators for the educational aspirations construct. Since we measured interest in the respective domain with only one item, we added these constructs to the model as manifest variables. In all analyses, we used maximum likelihood with robust standard errors (MLR) as the estimator due to the slight nonnormality in the measures. We used chi-square (c 2 ), the Comparative Fit Index (CFI), the Tucker-Lewis Index (TLI) and the Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA) as model-fit indicators. The CFI and TLI vary along a 0-to-1 continuum, and values greater than 0.90 and 0.95 typically reflect acceptable and excellent fit to the data, respectively. RMSEA values of less than 0.05 and 0.08 reflect a close fit and a reasonable fit to the data, respectively (Marsh, Hau, & Wen, 2004) . To be able to test the significance of indirect effects bootstrap confidence intervals (95%) with 1000 bootstrap draws were used (Preacher & Hayes, 2008; Shrout & Bolger, 2002) . The indirect effect can be considered to be statistically significant if the confidence interval excludes zero.

A prerequisite for a meaningful group comparison is that the measures are invariant across groupsdi.e., they measure the same underlying construct(s). Multiple group confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) allows for testing measurement invariance by specifying a series of nested models, where the endpoints are the least restrictive model with no invariance constraints, and the most restrictive model constrains all parameters to be the same across all groups (Bollen, 1989) . One can use chi-square difference testing to measure the statistical significance between nested models (Bentler, 1990) . Another viable option is to compare fit indices between models (Chen, 2007) . Since chi-square difference testing tends to be biased toward significance when the sample size is large (see Marsh, Hau, Balla, & Grayson, 1998) , we decided to compare the models in terms of fit indices (CFI and RMSEA). According to Chen (2007) , support for the more parsimonious model requires a change in CFI (DCFI) of less than 0.01 or a change in RMSEA (DRMSEA) of less than 0.015.

The modelling started with establishing measurement invariance for boys and girls by fitting a series of multiple group CFAs to the data. We first specified a model imposing no invariance constraints on the factor loadings and indicator intercepts, but assuming the same factor structure (configural invariance) in both groups, and we used this model as a baseline for testing measurement invariance. This model fitted the data very well

Next, to explore different pathways from the predictor variables to educational aspirations we fitted a series of multi-group structural equation models to the data. In the first model all predictor variables were allowed to have direct but no indirect effects to educational aspirations. This model fit the data reasonably well [c 2 (598) ¼ 1925.936, p < 0.001, CFI ¼ 0.884, TLI ¼ 0.874, RMSEA ¼ 0.062], and there were some differences across gender. Academic self-concept (ASC) and interest in reading predicted educational aspirations for both groups, whereas achievement in mathematics predicted educational aspirations only for boys. Additionally, for girls, school burnout (SBO) and interest in mathematics had positive direct effects on educational aspirations. In the second model ASC were again allowed to have a direct effect on educational aspirations, whereas achievement in reading and SBO predicted educational aspirations through interest in reading and achievement in mathematics and SBO predicted educational aspirations through interest in mathematics [c 2 (604) ¼ 1542.916, p < 0.001, CFI ¼ 0.919, TLI ¼ 0.913, RMSEA ¼ 0.052]. ASC and interest in reading were again significant predictors of educational aspirations for both groups and SBO (negatively) and achievement predicted interest in both domains. Interest in mathematics was a significant predictor for educational aspirations only for girls. Reading (positive) and SBO (negative) had significant indirect effects across gender, whereas achievement in mathematics only had a significant indirect effect for girls. In line with the gender differences found in the direct effects model modification indices suggested that achievement in mathematics and SBO should also have direct effects to educational aspirations.
body_text.section: Predicting educational aspirations with academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading

body_text.text: Based on these exploratory models and the literature we specified a modified model (Figs. 2 and 3) , where we set mathematics achievement and school burnout to predict interest in mathematics. We also set reading achievement and school burnout to predict interest in reading. Further, we set academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement in mathematics, and interest in mathematics and reading to predict educational aspirations simultaneously for boys and girls. The model described the data well and explained 33.2% of the variance in educational aspirations for boys and 34.4% of the variance in educational aspirations for girls [ c 2 (600) ¼ 1534.398, p < 0.001, CFI ¼ 0.920, TLI ¼ 0.913,
body_text.section: Predicting educational aspirations with academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading

body_text.text: RMSEA ¼ 0.052].
body_text.section: Predicting educational aspirations with academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading

body_text.text: Reading achievement predicted interest in reading, which, in turn, predicted educational aspirations for both genders. Similarly, mathematics achievement predicted interest in mathematics in both groups, while it had a direct effect only on boys' educational aspirations. Interest in mathematics predicted educational aspirations for girls, but not for boys. Academic self-concept predicted educational aspirations positively for both genders. School burnout had a negative effect on interest in both domains for both genders. The path from school burnout to educational aspirations was positive and significant for girls, whereas the path was non-significant for boys.
body_text.section: Predicting educational aspirations with academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading

body_text.text: To further examine whether the strengths of the differing paths differ, a model where the paths from SBO, achievement in mathematics, and interest in mathematics to educational aspirations were fixed to equality across gender, was fitted to the data. This model [c 2 (603) ¼ 1543.905, p < 0.001, CFI ¼ 0.919, TLI ¼ 0.913, RMSEA ¼ 0.052; DCFI ¼ 0.001, DRMSEA ¼ 0.000] did not differ significantly from the modified model. However, as the models are rather complex, small improvements do not necessarily impact the total model fit that much (Kenny & McCoach, 2003) . We therefore tested separately if the three regression coefficients differed significantly between boys and girls using the formula (1) recommended by Paternoster, Brame, Mazerolle, & Piquero, 1998 . The strength of the direct effect from SBO to educational aspirations was not significantly different from zero (z ¼ À0.86 p ¼ 0.39), whereas, for both achievement (z ¼ 2.07, p < 0.05) and interest in mathematics (z ¼ À2.71, p < 0.01), the strength of the paths differed significantly between boys and girls. body_text.section: Predicting educational aspirations with academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading

body_text.text: We also calculated the indirect effects of reading, mathematics and school burnout on educational aspirations using the Mplus model indirect command and bootstrapping. In addition, we also calculated the total effects of reading and mathematics achievement to get a measure of the relative strength of both achievement variables on educational aspirations. Reading achievement had a significant indirect effect on educational aspirations through interest in reading for both the boys and girls. This finding suggest that higher reading achievement leads to higher interest, which in turn leads to higher aspirations. We also found a similar path concerning mathematics for girls but not for boys. Mathematics achievement had an indirect effect on aspirations through interest in mathematics for girls. The total effect of mathematics achievement on aspirations was significant for boys but not for girls, whereas the total effect of reading achievement on aspirations was significant for girls but not for boys (Table 2) . We interpret this finding showing that overall, reading achievement is more important for girls' educational aspirations compared to mathematics achievement, while the opposite is true for boys.
body_text.section: Predicting educational aspirations with academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading

body_text.text: For boys, school burnout had a small, negative, indirect effect (b ¼ À0.03 95% CI [À0.05, À0.01]) on educational aspirations through interest in reading. For girls, the negative indirect effects from school burnout on educational aspirations came via interest in reading (b ¼ À0.02 95% CI [À0.04, À0.01]) and interest in mathematics (b ¼ À0.06 95% CI [À0.09, À0.02]). These indirect effects suggest that higher school burnout lowers interest, which in turn lowers aspirations.
body_text.section: Predicting educational aspirations with academic self-concept, school burnout, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading

body_text.text: In this study our aim was to investigate the role of academic selfconcept, school burnout, achievement and interest in mathematics and reading in educational aspirations among adolescents during their last year of compulsory education. As previous findings have been contradictory in terms of gender differences in the relationships between these factors, and studies combining two academic domains in the examinations are scarce, no specific expectations were made regarding the gender effects. Our results extend previous knowledge by examining educational aspirations as an outcome of several academic, motivational, and socio-emotional variables, and in relation to two different academic domains. While certain factors seemed to be influential for students' academic aspirations irrespective of gender, some interesting differences with important educational implications also emerged.

As to our first research question, we found that interest in reading predicted educational aspirations directly for both genders, whereas the effect of reading achievement was indirect, mediated by interest in reading. In other words, students with high reading achievement were also more likely to show interest in reading, and set higher educational aspirations. These results fit well with the literature on educational aspirations suggesting that motivational beliefs mediate the relationship between achievement and educational aspirations (e.g., Parker et al., 2014) . However, the total effect (the sum of direct and indirect effects between two variables) of reading achievement on educational aspirations was not significant for boys, which implies that reading achievement overall did not play a significant part in boys' aspirations besides the small indirect effect via interest. Previous studies examining the effects of reading achievement and interest have not found clear gender differences with regard to reading-related educational aspirations (Durik et al., 2006) or educational choices (Savolainen et al., 2008) , but these studies did not include a contrasted academic domain, and used a domain-specific outcome measure.

As regards mathematics (research question two), achievement predicted educational aspirations directly only for boys, while the effect was indirect for girls, mediated by their interest in mathematics. For both genders, high mathematics achievement was related to high interest in the domain, but for boys, the level of interest was not predictive of their educational aspirations. Previous studies have suggested that when making educational or occupational choices related to mathematics or the STEM-fields in general, boys tend to rely more on achievement in their decisionmaking processes (Nagy et al., 2006; Viljaranta et al., 2009) , while girls' choices are more directed by their interests (Chow et al., 2012; Watt et al., 2012) . Although in this study, the focus was not on students' domain-specific choices but the level of their general educational aspirations, it seems that a similar trend applies: for boys, mathematics achievement plays more an important role than interest in how high they aim in education, while the opposite seems to be more typical for girls. Furthermore, contrary to the effects of reading achievement, the total effect of mathematics achievement on educational aspirations was significant for boys but not for girls. In other words, reading achievement seemed to be more important for girls' aspirations, while mathematics achievement seemed to be more important for boys' aspirations.

One approach for discussing the predictor effects stemming from two different academic domains is the I/E model (Marsh, 1986) that postulates cross-domain effects between contrasted domain-specific achievement and motivational beliefs (i.e., selfconcept and interest). In addition, it has been suggested that gender could moderate the internal and external comparison processes related to students' ability and value perceptions (Eccles, 2009; Nagy et al., 2006) . In other words, in line with gendertypical biases (Meece, Glienke, & Burg, 2006) , it might be expected that boys would show more confidence in and place more value on mathematics, while girls would emphasize their reading competencies and interest. Further, it could be suggested that due to the comparison processes, the priority placed on these domains would result in different predictive effects on educational aspirations as a function of gender. Based on this reasoning, in our study, the reading domain should have been a stronger predictor of girls' aspirations than the mathematics domain, and the opposite pattern would have applied for boys.

Our results concerning the effects of reading and mathematics achievement can be taken to partly reflect the rationale behind the I/E model and gender-typical comparison processes. It seems that boys identify themselves more strongly with the mathematics domain than with the reading domain and consequently, place more emphasis on mathematics achievement, while the opposite pattern may be more likely for girls. This was reflected in the gendered pathways from the effects of achievement on educational aspirations. It is worth noting that although the total effects were non-significant there was still small significant indirect effects through interest in the gender-atypical domain for both genders. This finding suggest that within these domains, in order for achievement to have an effect on aspirations, the student should be interested. However, our results displayed a somewhat different pattern of associations in terms of interest measures. First, girls' educational aspirations were predicted by both interest in reading and mathematics, the latter showing a stronger effect. This result is comparable to Nagy et al. (2006) finding suggesting that for girls, intrinsic values related to contrasted academic domains seem to develop independently of each other. Second, we did not find indications of the cross-domain effects concerning interest for boys either. Rather, our results suggested that for boys, achievement is more important in terms of mathematics, while interest in reading also contributes to their educational aspirations. To conclude, we found some indications of the dimensional comparison processes with regard to achievement but not with regard to interest. Unfortunately, our study lacked measures of students' domain-specific self-concept that would have been interesting to include in the model in order to interpret the results more closely within the I/E model framework.

In terms of research question three, as expected, academic selfconcept had a positive direct effect on educational aspirations for both boys and girls, and it also turned out to be the strongest predictor among the variables. One explanation for this could be that academic self-concept is a domain-general construct, whereas we measured interest with domain-specific measures, hence dividing the interest effects between reading and mathematics. Furthermore, results might have differed between genders if domain-specific self-concept had been measured. The finding could also relate to educational culture, as previous cross-cultural research has found cultural differences in the strength of the relationships between self-concept, interest, and educational aspirations (Watt et al., 2012) . In Finland, after completing compulsory education, students choose between general upper secondary education (academic track) and vocational upper secondary education (vocational track). In general, it is more difficult to get admitted to general upper secondary, and therefore students' beliefs in their abilities are probably more important than their interests during this transition from lower secondary to upper secondary education. The result also highlights the importance of academic self-concept for students' educational aspirations. Promoting students' selfconcept is not only important for their achievement (Marsh et al., 2002) , but also for their future educational careers (Nagengast & Marsh, 2012) .

Finally, school burnout had a negative, indirect effect through interest in reading and mathematics on educational aspirations in both groups. In addition, higher level of school burnout was directly related to higher level of educational aspirations for girls, whereas this effect was not observed among boys. In line with recent studies on the consequences of students' socio-emotional strain (Flake et al., 2015; Gaspard et al., 2015; Perez et al., 2014) , school burnout negatively predicted interest in both reading and mathematics, and through them, educational aspirations. Our study thus adds to existing literature by demonstrating the association of school burnout with students' educational aspirations, even when controlling for achievement, interest and self-concept. This result can also be taken to support the importance of including the cost component in the expectancy-value model. Even though cost is an established part of the model theoretically (Wigfield & Cambria, 2010) , empirical studies have only recently started to acknowledge it. Especially, it would be important to examine the consequences of prolonged cost, of which school burnout might be one possibility (Salmela-Aro & Upadyaya, 2014a) .

Surprisingly, we also found a positive direct effect of school burnout on educational aspirations for girls. It is possible that ambitious and success-oriented girls investing more effort in school may experience higher levels of school burnout, while at the same time holding high educational goals and plans (Tuominen-Soini & Salmela-Aro, 2014; Tuominen-Soini et al., 2008) . This path was not significant for boys, which is in line with previous findings showing that even though girls are more engaged in school (Martin, 2004) , they may feel more stress as a result of the demands they set upon themselves (Matud, 2004; Salmela-Aro & Tynkkynen, 2012) . However, this particular result is highly speculative in terms of gendered effects, as the regression slopes did not significantly differ between boys and girls. We can therefore not rule out the possibility that this mechanism might also be present in boys, even though we did not detect it.

The results of the present study can be taken to emphasize the importance of nourishing adolescents' interests in different academic domains. While the girls' lower interest in mathematics is already a well-recognized topic (Frenzel, Goetz, Pekrun, & Watt, 2010) , less attention has been paid to the level of boys' interest in reading, which in our study proved to be beneficial for their educational aspirations. The fact that interest in mathematics was not related to boys' educational aspirations does not mean that it should be ignored: interest can be considered as an educational outcome also in its own right (Renninger & Hidi, 2011) . Although there are no clear-cut guidelines for increasing students' interest through instructional practices, research suggest that providing students with possibility of choice, authentic and real-life examples, explicating the utility value of the learning content, and connecting it with students' own personal goals and values, may be beneficial for both their motivation and learning (Dewolf, Van Dooren, & Verschaffel, 2011; Harackiewicz, Canning, Tibbetts, Priniski, & Hyde, 2015; Høgheim & Reber, 2015) .

Our findings also illustrate that in terms of the level of adolescents' future educational aims, the three factors examined simultaneously in this study, achievement, motivational beliefs, and socio-emotional resources, all matter. Therefore, problems in any of these should be recognized as early as possible in order to support adolescents' desire to set challenging educational goals. As the last grade of compulsory school is a demanding phase for some of the students (Salmela-Aro & Upadyaya, 2014b), resources should be targeted for the availability of school counsellors, and besides students' academic achievement, attention should be paid to their motivation and socio-emotional well-being. Echoing previous studies, school burnout was shown to have maladaptive consequences (Korhonen et al., 2014; Salmela-Aro, Savolainen, et al., 2009) . Practical means to intervene and to provide all adolescents with adequate coping strategies should be developed. Concrete advice on how to prevent and handle feelings of exhaustion and negative affect, might save from more severe problems later on, as the study-related demands are likely to increase in the course of education.

This study had several limitations that are relevant when interpreting the results. It is worth noting that we used teacherrated interest in mathematics and reading, which may not fully capture or correspond to the student's subjective experience.

Previous research has indicated that high student achievement has a positive effect on teacher perceptions (Sweet, Guthrie, & Ng, 1998; Tiedemann, 2002) , so also teachers' interest-ratings may have been biased by students' achievement in the given domain. It is also possible that gender affects teachers' evaluations of student characteristics (Mullola et al., 2012) and hence, the results concerning interest must be interpreted cautiously. However, interest has been defined as a motivational variable that on its part describes the quality of student engagement (Ainley, 2012) , and it can be suggested that teacher evaluations reflect adolescents' engagement from the perspective of their classroom behaviour and task involvement (e.g., Wigfield et al., 2008) . Moreover, we were able to identify significant effects from the interest measures to educational aspirations even after controlling for students' school achievement. A further limitation is that we used a domain general measure of academic self-concept instead of domain-specific measures in reading and mathematics. This prevented us from disentangling possible gender effects in how reading and mathematics self-concepts predict educational aspirations. We suggest that future studies also use domain-specific measures of selfconcept. Finally, as developmental processes are important when studying the relations between achievement and different motivational beliefs, a longitudinal design would be warranted. Likewise, although aspirations predict actual educational attainment and career choice, future studies could follow their participants through tertiary education to working life.

Our results emphasize that in order to better understand the formation of adolescents' educational aims, several factors should be considered simultaneously. As students' motivational beliefs are differentiated across academic domains and by gender, examining their concurrent effects may produce different results than when focusing only on one domain at a time. We found evidence of both between-and within-domain gender differences in how achievement and interest predicts aspirations. More specifically, mathematics achievement had a stronger and direct effect on educational aspirations for boys, while reading achievement was more important for girls. In this respect, our results can be taken to reflect the gender-typical comparison processes between the two domains. However, interest in reading predicted educational aspirations for both genders, while interest in mathematics only predicted girls' educational aspirations. While warranting replication, in our study, gender-atypical interests also seemed to play a role in the level of adolescents' educational aspirations. Regarding school burnout and educational aspirations our study showed that their relationship was mainly mediated by the interest variables. However, for girls, school burnout also had a positive direct effect on educational aspirations. Thus, we believe that our study both corroborated and extended the previous research not only by combining the two contrasted but central academic domains, mathematics and reading, in the same study design, but also by taking into account indices of students' academic well-being. Besides achievement, motivation and emotional resources are needed to support adolescents' striving towards their desired educational goals.

FIGREF0.text: Theoretical path model predicting educational aspirations. ASC ¼ academic self-concept; SBO ¼ school burnout; exh ¼ exhaustion; inad ¼ inadequacy; cyn ¼ cynicism; R INT ¼ interest in reading; M INT ¼ interest in math; EDU ¼ educational aspirations. b1-b9 ¼ items from the school burnout inventory; s1-s8 ¼ items from the perceived comptence scale for children; lslp ¼ reading comprehension composite score; lsop ¼ word comprehesnion composite score; m1-m4 ¼ item parcels based on the KTLT math test; vill ¼ idealistic educational aspirations; tro ¼ realistic educational aspirations.

TABREF0.text: Correlations and descriptive statistics and internal consistencies for all measures.

TABREF1.text: [c 2 (480) ¼ 1125.218, p < 0.001, CFI ¼ 0.938, TLI ¼ 0.929, RMSEA ¼ 0.048]. Next, we fitted a model where the factor loadings were constrained to equality (factorial invariance) across groups, and this did not worsen the model fit [c 2 (497) ¼ 1141.325, p < 0.001, CFI ¼ 0.939, TLI ¼ 0.932, RMSEA ¼ 0.048; DCFI ¼ 0.001, DRMSEA ¼ 0.000]. We then compared the factorial invariance model against a fully invariant model, where we also constrained the indicator intercepts to equality (scalar invariance). The fully invariant model fitted the data well and did not worsen the model fit [c 2 (514) ¼ 1260.198, p < 0.001, CFI ¼ 0.929, TLI ¼ 0.924, RMSEA ¼ 0.050; DCFI ¼ 0.01, DRMSEA ¼ 0.002]. To conclude, we clearly achieved the prerequisite for meaningful group comparison, measurement invariance.
